posts.cooked: Hi guys, our team is using an alignment system with odometry and when it gets close to the reef it does a 3D alignment to align with precision, to be able to align by telemetry we are using pathfinder, however when the command is scheduled there is a delay of about 2 seconds, how can we get around this so that the command responds immediately?

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked:
Does it only happen the first time you schedule it?  I’m thinking it might be related to this:

From the PathPlanner docs ( Pathfinding | PathPlanner Docs )

Due to the nature of how Java works, the first run of a pathfinding command could have a significantly higher delay compared with subsequent runs.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: Be carful with this as the built in pathplanner commands will refuse to run if you are within half a meter of the target. I would personally recommend writing your own basic auto drive with pid. Its super easy and I can send you ours if you want.

posts.name: Vihaan C
posts.cooked: I have seen this behavior as well. Do you think it has to do with the algorithm used? Just thinking as path finding is still a useful feature. Maybe if you still want to use path finding, you could path find to be infront of the reef and then create a drive command to the point.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked:
Our system uses the pathplanner autodrive unless we are within 0.5 of a meter in which case it swaps to the custom one. Generally if you are within half a meter of the target you prob have a straight shot anyway so path planning isn’t really necessary.

The reason pathplanner quits within that distance is that if the start and end points are too close pathplanner can get confused and think that the start point is the same as the end point (since it understand space as a grid of 0.3m squares). Because of this the pathplanner devs made stuff quit within that distance to avoid any weird behavior.

posts.name: Vihaan C
posts.cooked: What do you mean by “auto drive” and what custom drive are you saying? Just curious. Otherwise, the logic about that makes sense, thanks .

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked:
By autodrive I just mean a command that drives the robot to a point automatically, like the kind used in auto align.

The custom drive can be anything (as long as it can handle distances less than half a meter) but we just use a pid on the distance and point the robot at the goal.

Hope that helps :).

There is a warmup command you can use

https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-pathfinding.html#java-warmup

For short distances we are aligning using the limelight’s 3D view, thus making small rotation corrections and alignment on the X and Y axis, do you think it’s valid? The telemetry issue would be more to optimize time, for example, I’m at the coral station and the path to my side of the reef is not obstructed, so I click on a button and it goes close to where I want to score and thus activates the limelight’s 3D alignment to make small adjustments, and we also created a command that only switches to the 3D alignment if it is very close to where we want to score to avoid these pathfinder errors.

VihaanC:

I have seen this behavior as well. Do you think it has to do with the algorithm used? Just thinking as path finding is still a useful feature. Maybe if you still want to use path finding, you could path find to be infront of the reef and then create a drive command to the point.

Could you send that our way? This is the strategy we are taking and would love to see how another team did it, even if we think we have the code set up already

posts.name: Jay Ticku
posts.cooked: We’re using PathPlanner as well for an auto align function that aligns to the reef. We’ve also noticed that the command takes about two seconds for the robot to start driving, however we are using python. I’m thinking this might be an algorithm issue. Would you have any ideas on how to remove this delay?

posts.name: Vihaan C
posts.cooked:
jayticku:

Would you have any ideas on how to remove this delay?

Sadly, I am not sure. I was thinking to do the pathfinding Java warmup but since you are using python that would not apply. Doing a quick search I found your thread describing that the issue possibly not be just python based. I found this thread that may describe how to fix your issues in Java. You could translate this in python.

link_counts.title: PathPlanner Initial Lag after Deploying Code

posts.name: Vihaan C
posts.cooked: Below is the code. The keybinds in this case are left bumper to go to the nearest side on the reef on the left most branch and the right bumper is to go to the nearest side of the reef on the right most branch. The movement is to pathfind to 0.5 meters away from the nearest side of the reef and then move forward. This is to add time to move the elevator up as well as fixing the issue that path planner does not path find when at a certain distance from the target.

posts.name: Jay Ticku
posts.cooked: The interesting part is that it’s not actually a first command delay. It seems to be that whenever we run the command, we always get like a one to two second delay. We are using command based, so could it have something to do with that?

posts.name: Vihaan C
posts.cooked: I am not really sure. Sorry I can’t help you.
